title: On Adversarial Attacks In Acoustic Drone Localization
author: Tamir Shor (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology), Chaim Baskin (Ben-Gurion University of the Negev), Alex Bronstein (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology), ..., Alex Bronstein (Institute of Science and Technology, Austria)
relevance_why: The paper addresses adversarial attacks in acoustic localization which could inform similar vulnerabilities and defenses in audio-speech systems, particularly in drone navigation and sound capture.
background: Investigating how adversarial audio signals can disrupt drone localization, which relies on acoustic sensing systems rather than visual cues.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework to analyze and mitigate adversarial attacks on acoustic drone localization, achieving significant localization recovery from adversarial noise.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused primarily on visual adversarial attacks, lacking techniques related to acoustic sensing and its vulnerabilities.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work extends the adversarial attack framework to acoustic systems, proposing robust algorithms for acoustic perturbation recovery.

key_innovation: Develops a novel defense mechanism using phase modulation to recover original sound signals, effectively distinguishing adversarial noise.
real_world_impact: Enhancing the safety and reliability of drone operations in real-world environments by addressing vulnerabilities to acoustic adversarial attacks can have wide implications in sectors like delivery and emergency services.
limitations: No explicit limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.adversarial attacks: **Adversarial attacks** are malicious modifications to input data intended to deceive machine learning models into making incorrect predictions.
new_terms.acoustic localization: **Acoustic localization** refers to determining the position of sound sources using measurements from microphones, often affected by environmental factors.

open_sourcing: The code for reproducing all experiments will be released upon publication.
